--- title: "Functions" format: html: toc: false section-divs: true include-after-body: - text: | engine: knitr filters: - webr webr: cell-options: editor-font-scale: 0.85 fig-width: 6 fig-height: 3.7 out-width: "70%" --- ### Functions {.no-hide} Watch [this video](https://vimeo.com/220490105): ```{=html}
``` ### Run a function Can you use the `sqrt()` function in the chunk below to compute the square root of 962? ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ``` ## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution ```r sqrt(962) ``` ::: ### Code Use the code chunk below to examine the code that `sqrt()` runs. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ``` ## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution ```r sqrt ``` ::: ### Good job! `sqrt` immediately triggers a low level algorithm optimized for performance, so there is not much code to see. ### lm Compare the code in `sqrt()` to the code in another R function, `lm()`. Examine `lm()`'s code body in the chunk below. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ``` ## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution ```r lm ``` ::: ### Help pages Wow! `lm()` runs a lot of code. What does it do? Open the help page for `lm()` in the chunk below and find out. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ?lm ``` ## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution ```r ?lm ``` ::: ### Good job! `lm()` is R's function for fitting basic linear models. No wonder it runs so much code. ### Code comments What do you think the chunk below will return? Run it and see. The result should be nothing. R will not run anything on a line after a `#` symbol. This is useful because it lets you write human readable comments in your code: just place the comments after a `#`. Now delete the `#` and re-run the chunk. You should see a result. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} # sqrt(962) ``` ## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution ```r sqrt(962) ``` ::: ##
